init_text:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion,

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: While our screens are addicting, there's nothing inherently wrong with using them in the right way.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: And, indeed, for some people, the Internet can be a real lifeline.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: a recent scientific study shows that a slight increase in Facebook use can actually be a good thing for people with disabilities--if it's used in a healthy

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: this social network lets people with disabilities communicate with others who are similar, at a time when they might otherwise feel alone in their social world.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: , who was born with cerebral palsy, who uses Facebook to communicate with other people in her situation--something none of us would be able to do

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: , "Thank God for Facebook," because, without it, she would feel a little more alone in a world of able-bodied people.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: of her viewpoint and that it's perfectly OK to balance screen time with face-to-face, real-world interactions.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: My niece, Everly, is a great example of how that balance can work.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: Everly is a typical nine-year-old girl, with an Internet-savvy iPhone and an iPad 2.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: She usually spends a little time on each of these gadgets each day.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: Her favorite apps are games, which are understandably popular with kids her age.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: But a recent study shows that Everly's screen time is still well within recommended limits.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: She hasn't forgotten how to play with dolls, act out stories or read books.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: In other words, she balances her time between the "real" world and the digital one--and that's a good thing.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: So what's the best way to achieve a healthy balance?

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: With my kids, we've found that we need to start with a chat about how we can be better digital citizens.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: being a good citizen of the Internet means that she should use her technology responsibly.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: It also means that she shouldn't spend too much time on her devices--not because technology or the Internet are bad, but because life is messy,

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: and her brother, Bryson, get it; they know that many things in life--and especially life online--are about balance.

actions.name: text-insert
actions.text: encourages smart use of technology--such as putting away devices for dinner and, if necessary, limiting screen time.

actions.name: text-insert

actions.text: there's the balance--social time with family, physical recreation, even a little bit of time spent cooking.
